entry.title: How ETH Is Received in Smart Contracts
entry.summary:
How ETH Is Received in Smart Contracts ‚Äî receive(), fallback(), and Common Mistakes
Smart contracts on Ethereum can receive ETH directly. But what actually happens when someone sends ETH to a contract? And why do some transactions fail silently while others go through? Let‚Äôs dive deep into how Ether is handled in Solidity, the differences between receive() and fallback(), and some key developer mistakes you should avoid. When you send ETH to a contract, one of two functions will be triggered based on the context: receive() external payable fallback() external payable These are special functions in Solidity that aren‚Äôt called directly in code. They get triggered under very specific circumstances. receive() Run?
The receive() function runs when: A contract receives ETH with empty calldat‚Ä¶

entry.title: My two cents about drupal templates marketplaces

Although the idea of a Drupal template marketplace seems like a good idea to me and could be a good boost for Drupal as a product and therefore for the Drupal community, these are my doubts, fears, or a mix of everything. When we talk about a Drupal template marketplace, the WordPress marketplace comes to mind. It's true that this marketplace works and has possibly been one of WordPress's successes in becoming the product it is today, as it allowed someone without technical knowledge to have a beautiful and operational website. entry.title: Style Guide Proposal: Parentheses and Braces in PHP
Top IAM Challenges in Multi-Cloud Environments and How to Solve¬†Them
entry.summary: As businesses continue migrating workloads to cloud platforms like AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud, one thing becomes clear‚Äîmanaging Identity and Access Management (IAM) across multiple cloud environments is no simple task. Without a cohesive strategy, organizations face increased risk, inconsistent access controls, and compliance blind spots. In this article, we break down the top IAM challenges enterprises face in multi-cloud setups and how to address them with scalable, secure solutions. Each cloud provider has its own IAM structure. AWS uses IAM roles and policies, Azure relies on role-based access control (RBAC), and GCP leverages Identity-Aware Proxy and IAM roles. The challenge: Solution: In a multi-cloud setup, visibility into who has access to what‚Äîand when‚Äîis often fragmented. This ‚Ä¶

entry.title: My Experience with HyperlaneÔºà1749920788915700Ôºâ
entry.summary:
As a junior in computer science, I embarked on a project last semester to build a campus second-hand trading platform. This led me to discover the Hyperlane Rust HTTP framework. I was at a crossroads, needing a framework robust enough for peak end-of-semester trading and simple enough for a Rust novice like me to grasp quickly. Hyperlane didn't just meet my expectations; it exceeded them. I'm excited to share my journey with this impressive framework. ctx: A Thoughtfully Designed Abstraction
My initial foray into writing route functions with Hyperlane introduced me to its Context (or ctx). I was immediately struck by its design. I remember when I first needed to retrieve the request method. In more conventional Rust HTTP frameworks, the code would typically look like this: let method = c‚Ä¶

entry.title: From Hong Kong to Tokyo ‚Äî A Nonlinear Path into Tech
entry.summary:
This isn‚Äôt one of those stories where everything goes according to plan.
In fact, it rarely did. I didn‚Äôt get great grades in high school. I didn‚Äôt enter university right after. I even changed majors ‚Äî and later, careers. My path was all over the place. One day, while working in my old industry, I found myself asking: Why am I doing this? What‚Äôs the point? That question led to action.
I quit.
I joined a coding bootcamp.
I studied full-time for 4 months.
I landed my first role at an international blockchain company.
Then I left again‚Äîthis time, for Tokyo. After a year learning Japanese, I restarted my career here as a full-time software engineer at a startup. It‚Äôs been uncertain, messy, and totally worth it. You don‚Äôt need a perfect start to end up in a good place. Progress isn‚Äôt always loud ‚Äî but it compounds. Your past doesn‚Äôt disqualify your future. üìù I‚Äôm now documenting my thoughts on career, software, growth, and things I‚Äôm building ‚Äî both technically and personally. javaskr.com üëÄ I‚Äôve grown the most from working with teams that value curiosity, speed, and empathy ‚Äî happy to connect with folks who share that ‚Äî or you‚Äôre just curious about how I made the jump ‚Äî feel free to check out what I‚Äôve been working on (via LinkedIn, Medium‚Ä¶) You never know who you‚Äôll be tomorrow. Take the step today.

entry.title: Enhancing Claude Code with MCP Servers and Subagents
entry.summary:
Introduction
I've been using Claude Code daily for personal development projects. However, I've encountered several cases where Claude struggled to solve complex problems dependent on specific library versions during web app development. After extensive experimentation, I discovered that enabling Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers for Claude Code significantly improves its problem-solving capabilities. This article shares my findings and practical implementation. While Claude Code is powerful, it sometimes lacks current information about rapidly evolving libraries and frameworks. This limitation becomes particularly evident when dealing with: Version-specific compatibility issues Recent library updates and breaking changes Latest best practices and solutions Context7: Version-specific ‚Ä¶

entry.title: üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Runner H "AI Agent Prompting" Challenge
entry.summary:
This is a submission for the Runner H "AI Agent Prompting" Challenge I built a Job Search AI Agent that analyzes your resume and searches for job listings that best match your profile. Instead of manually filtering job boards, the AI reads your resume, understands your experience, and intelligently finds job opportunities aligned with your skills, role, and interests. It‚Äôs like having a personal AI recruiter that works on your behalf ‚Äî 24/7. Here‚Äôs how it works: Upload your resume (PDF or text) The AI parses your experience, skills, and role It then runs targeted searches across job boards Finally, it summarizes and suggests job listings that match your profile
How I Used Runner H
Runner H‚Äôs AI agent framework made it easier to structure tasks like: Resume parsing (using NLP) Role-based matching Job board search automation Prompt chaining to create a decision-making loop (e.g., reject mismatches, refine search) I built prompts that: Understand the candidate‚Äôs background Convert it into a structured "search query" Evaluate results based on match score and keywords Summarize the top roles with direct links It felt like using a smart co-pilot for job hunting. üìå Use Case: Instead of you finding jobs, jobs find you ‚Äî based on what you‚Äôre best at. üåç Impact: Saves time and mental effort Increases relevance of job matches Helps junior and mid-level devs who are unsure how to ‚Äúmarket‚Äù their resume This can easily be extended for recruiters, freelance platforms, or even career counselors. This challenge pushed me to build something not only technical, but practically useful in everyday life. üôè Shout-out to Runner H and Dev.to for encouraging creative use of AI agents. ü§ñ AI doesn‚Äôt just generate ‚Äî it can collaborate, assist, and elevate your job search game.

entry.title: Transport Minister: KEJARA Demerit System Is Not Working
entry.summary: Recently, the Transport Minister Anthony Loke said that the KEJARA driving license demerit points system needs to overhauled. He also added that the system is not working as it was intended to. For the uninitiated, KEJARA (Keselamatan Jalan Raya) is a Demerit Points System implemented in 1984 under the Motor Vehicles (Demerit Points) Rules 1997. entry.title: Shoring up global supply chains with generative AI
